diagrams.description: Venture Capital evolved from wealthy family investments to institutionalized asset class driving innovation economies. Early venture investments by wealthy individuals and families (1800s-early 1900s) funded railroads, oil, and manufacturing. The modern venture capital industry began with American Research and Development Corporation (1946), the first institutional VC firm, funding Digital Equipment Corporation's success. Silicon Valley emerged as venture hub in the 1960s-1970s with semiconductor and computer investments. The National Venture Capital Association formed in 1973 to represent the industry. Kleiner Perkins, Sequoia Capital, and other legendary firms established in the 1970s. Regulatory changes in 1979 allowed pension funds to invest in venture capital, dramatically expanding capital availability. The dot-com boom (1995-2000) brought unprecedented VC activity and subsequent bust correction. The rise of Google, Facebook, and social media (2000s) validated internet business models. Seed funding explosion and accelerator models like Y Combinator (2005) democratized early-stage investing. Today's venture capital integrates global reach, sector specialization, corporate venture arms, and emerging technologies like AI, blockchain, and biotechnology.

timeline
    title The History of Venture Capital
    section Early Days
        1946 : American Research and Development Corporation (ARDC) is founded
        1957 : ARDC's investment in DEC yields massive returns
        1958 : Small Business Investment Act
    section The Rise of Silicon Valley
        1972 : Kleiner Perkins and Sequoia Capital are founded
        1978 : "Prudent Man Rule" relaxed, allowing pensions to invest in VC
        1980s : Boom in technology startups (e.g., Apple, Genentech)
    section The Dot-Com Era
        1990s : The Dot-Com Boom
        2000 : The Dot-Com Crash
    section The 21st Century
        2000s : Rise of "Super Angel" investors
        2010s : Emergence of "Unicorns" & growth of mega-funds
